posts.name: Yuval Rashman
Joe Ross
posts.cooked: If it’s at one extreme and then you command the other extreme, and then disable, does it keep moving to the other extreme, or does it move to somewhere in the middle? What happens if you change the bounds to setBounds(MAX_PWM_PULSE, 0, 0, 0, MIN_PWM_PULSE); which is more similar to the Servo class

posts.name: Yuval Rashman
posts.cooked:
Joe_Ross:

extreme

It will go to the other extreme point, and I haven’t tried setting the bounds to 0,0,0 (I will try) but I took the values from the wcp manual https://wcproducts.info/files/frc/manuals/ WCP %20Miniature%20Linear%20Servo%20Actuators%20-%20User%20Guide.pdf

These values are also in the Andymark manual: https://andymark-weblinc.netdna-ssl.com/media/W1siZiIsIjIwMTkvMDMvMjIvMTAvMjkvNDEvYWViNDNlZDgtMWM3NC00NGY5LWIwMGMtNmRlNjE4Y2ExNjU5L1VzaW5nIEwxNiBMaW5lYXIgU2Vydm8gMDMtMjAxOS5wZGYiXV0/Using%20L16%20Linear%20Servo%2003-2019.pdf?sha=44e08f353d4bb9ec

MORE detail manual:

6.11 MB

posts.name: Yuval Rashman
posts.cooked: I believe the problem is that the roboRio doesn’t change its pwm value when disabled, Or the linearServo somehow remembers its last pwm value.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: I suspect the latter. A regular servo stops when disabled for me.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
The RoboRIO forces the PWM output to low the instant it is disabled:

image 1564×179 4.01 KB

image 1564×179 4.01 KB

image 1564×179 4.01 KB

(note the last pulse is shorter too because it was disabled mid pulse)

So what appears to be happening is the linear servo continues going to its last commanded position when the PWM pulse train is lost.

Regarding your second question, there is no rule that prohibits this behavior.
